1682 ImGuiStyleVar_FrameRounding, // float FrameRounding
1683 ImGuiStyleVar_FrameBorderSize, // float FrameBorderSize
1684 ImGuiStyleVar_ItemSpacing, // ImVec2 ItemSpacing
1685 ImGuiStyleVar_ItemInnerSpacing, // ImVec2 ItemInnerSpacing
1686 ImGuiStyleVar_IndentSpacing, // float IndentSpacing
1687 ImGuiStyleVar_CellPadding, // ImVec2 CellPadding
1688 ImGuiStyleVar_ScrollbarSize, // float ScrollbarSize
1689 ImGuiStyleVar_ScrollbarRounding, // float ScrollbarRounding
1690 ImGuiStyleVar_GrabMinSize, // float GrabMinSize
1691 ImGuiStyleVar_GrabRounding, // float GrabRounding
1692 ImGuiStyleVar_TabRounding, // float TabRounding
1693 ImGuiStyleVar_ButtonTextAlign, // ImVec2 ButtonTextAlign
1694 ImGuiStyleVar_SelectableTextAlign, // ImVec2 SelectableTextAlign
1695 ImGuiStyleVar_COUNT
1696};
1697
1698// Flags for InvisibleButton() [extended in imgui_internal.h]
1699enum ImGuiButtonFlags_
1700{
1701 ImGuiButtonFlags_None = 0,
1702 ImGuiButtonFlags_MouseButtonLeft = 1 << 0, // React on left mouse button (default)
1703 ImGuiButtonFlags_MouseButtonRight = 1 << 1, // React on right mouse button
1704 ImGuiButtonFlags_MouseButtonMiddle = 1 << 2, // React on center mouse button
1705
1706 // [Internal]
1707 ImGuiButtonFlags_MouseButtonMask_ = ImGuiButtonFlags_MouseButtonLeft | ImGuiButtonFlags_MouseButtonRight | ImGuiButtonFlags_MouseButtonMiddle,
1708 ImGuiButtonFlags_MouseButtonDefault_ = ImGuiButtonFlags_MouseButtonLeft
1709};
1710
1711// Flags for ColorEdit3() / ColorEdit4() / ColorPicker3() / ColorPicker4() / ColorButton()
1712enum ImGuiColorEditFlags_
1713{
1714 ImGuiColorEditFlags_None = 0,
1715 ImGuiColorEditFlags_NoAlpha = 1 << 1, // // ColorEdit, ColorPicker, ColorButton: ignore Alpha component (will only read 3 components from the input pointer).
1716 ImGuiColorEditFlags_NoPicker = 1 << 2, // // ColorEdit: disable picker when clicking on color square.
1717 ImGuiColorEditFlags_NoOptions = 1 << 3, // // ColorEdit: disable toggling options menu when right-clicking on inputs/small preview.
1718 ImGuiColorEditFlags_NoSmallPreview = 1 << 4, // // ColorEdit, ColorPicker: disable color square preview next to the inputs. (e.g. to show only the inputs)
1719 ImGuiColorEditFlags_NoInputs = 1 << 5, // // ColorEdit, ColorPicker: disable inputs sliders/text widgets (e.g. to show only the small preview color square).
1720 ImGuiColorEditFlags_NoTooltip = 1 << 6, // // ColorEdit, ColorPicker, ColorButton: disable tooltip when hovering the preview.
1721 ImGuiColorEditFlags_NoLabel = 1 << 7, // // ColorEdit, ColorPicker: disable display of inline text label (the label is still forwarded to the tooltip and picker).
1722 ImGuiColorEditFlags_NoSidePreview = 1 << 8, // // ColorPicker: disable bigger color preview on right side of the picker, use small color square preview instead.
1723 ImGuiColorEditFlags_NoDragDrop = 1 << 9, // // ColorEdit: disable drag and drop target. ColorButton: disable drag and drop source.
1724 ImGuiColorEditFlags_NoBorder = 1 << 10, // // ColorButton: disable border (which is enforced by default)
1725
1726 // User Options (right-click on widget to change some of them).
1727 ImGuiColorEditFlags_AlphaBar = 1 << 16, // // ColorEdit, ColorPicker: show vertical alpha bar/gradient in picker.
1728 ImGuiColorEditFlags_AlphaPreview = 1 << 17, // // ColorEdit, ColorPicker, ColorButton: display preview as a transparent color over a checkerboard, instead of opaque.
1729 ImGuiColorEditFlags_AlphaPreviewHalf= 1 << 18, // // ColorEdit, ColorPicker, ColorButton: display half opaque / half checkerboard, instead of opaque.
1730 ImGuiColorEditFlags_HDR = 1 << 19, // // (WIP) ColorEdit: Currently only disable 0.0f..1.0f limits in RGBA edition (note: you probably want to use ImGuiColorEditFlags_Float flag as well).
1731 ImGuiColorEditFlags_DisplayRGB = 1 << 20, // [Display] // ColorEdit: override _display_ type among RGB/HSV/Hex. ColorPicker: select any combination using one or more of RGB/HSV/Hex.
1732 ImGuiColorEditFlags_DisplayHSV = 1 << 21, // [Display] // "
1733 ImGuiColorEditFlags_DisplayHex = 1 << 22, // [Display] // "
1734 ImGuiColorEditFlags_Uint8 = 1 << 23, // [DataType] // ColorEdit, ColorPicker, ColorButton: _display_ values formatted as 0..255.
1735 ImGuiColorEditFlags_Float = 1 << 24, // [DataType] // ColorEdit, ColorPicker, ColorButton: _display_ values formatted as 0.0f..1.0f floats instead of 0..255 integers. No round-trip of value via integers.
1736 ImGuiColorEditFlags_PickerHueBar = 1 << 25, // [Picker] // ColorPicker: bar for Hue, rectangle for Sat/Value.
1737 ImGuiColorEditFlags_PickerHueWheel = 1 << 26, // [Picker] // ColorPicker: wheel for Hue, triangle for Sat/Value.
1738 ImGuiColorEditFlags_InputRGB = 1 << 27, // [Input] // ColorEdit, ColorPicker: input and output data in RGB format.
1739 ImGuiColorEditFlags_InputHSV = 1 << 28, // [Input] // ColorEdit, ColorPicker: input and output data in HSV format.
1740
1741 // Defaults Options. You can set application defaults using SetColorEditOptions(). The intent is that you probably don't want to
1742 // override them in most of your calls. Let the user choose via the option menu and/or call SetColorEditOptions() once during startup.
1743 ImGuiColorEditFlags_DefaultOptions_ = ImGuiColorEditFlags_Uint8 | ImGuiColorEditFlags_DisplayRGB | ImGuiColorEditFlags_InputRGB | ImGuiColorEditFlags_PickerHueBar,
1744
1745 // [Internal] Masks
1746 ImGuiColorEditFlags_DisplayMask_ = ImGuiColorEditFlags_DisplayRGB | ImGuiColorEditFlags_DisplayHSV | ImGuiColorEditFlags_DisplayHex,
1747 ImGuiColorEditFlags_DataTypeMask_ = ImGuiColorEditFlags_Uint8 | ImGuiColorEditFlags_Float,
1748 ImGuiColorEditFlags_PickerMask_ = ImGuiColorEditFlags_PickerHueWheel | ImGuiColorEditFlags_PickerHueBar,
1749 ImGuiColorEditFlags_InputMask_ = ImGuiColorEditFlags_InputRGB | ImGuiColorEditFlags_InputHSV
1750
1751 // Obsolete names (will be removed)
1752 // ImGuiColorEditFlags_RGB = ImGuiColorEditFlags_DisplayRGB, ImGuiColorEditFlags_HSV = ImGuiColorEditFlags_DisplayHSV, ImGuiColorEditFlags_HEX = ImGuiColorEditFlags_DisplayHex // [renamed in 1.69]
1753};
1754
1755// Flags for DragFloat(), DragInt(), SliderFloat(), SliderInt() etc.
1756// We use the same sets of flags for DragXXX() and SliderXXX() functions as the features are the same and it makes it easier to swap them.
1757enum ImGuiSliderFlags_
1758{
1759 ImGuiSliderFlags_None = 0,
1760 ImGuiSliderFlags_AlwaysClamp = 1 << 4, // Clamp value to min/max bounds when input manually with CTRL+Click. By default CTRL+Click allows going out of bounds.
1761 ImGuiSliderFlags_Logarithmic = 1 << 5, // Make the widget logarithmic (linear otherwise). Consider using ImGuiSliderFlags_NoRoundToFormat with this if using a format-string with small amount of digits.
1762 ImGuiSliderFlags_NoRoundToFormat = 1 << 6, // Disable rounding underlying value to match precision of the display format string (e.g. %.3f values are rounded to those 3 digits)
1763 ImGuiSliderFlags_NoInput = 1 << 7, // Disable CTRL+Click or Enter key allowing to input text directly into the widget
1764 ImGuiSliderFlags_InvalidMask_ = 0x7000000F // [Internal] We treat using those bits as being potentially a 'float power' argument from the previous API that has got miscast to this enum, and will trigger an assert if needed.
1765
1766 // Obsolete names (will be removed)
1767#ifndef IMGUI_DISABLE_OBSOLETE_FUNCTIONS
1768 , ImGuiSliderFlags_ClampOnInput = ImGuiSliderFlags_AlwaysClamp // [renamed in 1.79]
1769#endif
1770};
1771
1772// Identify a mouse button.
1773// Those values are guaranteed to be stable and we frequently use 0/1 directly. Named enums provided for convenience.
1774enum ImGuiMouseButton_
1775{
1776 ImGuiMouseButton_Left = 0,
1777 ImGuiMouseButton_Right = 1,
1778 ImGuiMouseButton_Middle = 2,
1779 ImGuiMouseButton_COUNT = 5
1780};
1781
1782// Enumeration for GetMouseCursor()
1783// User code may request backend to display given cursor by calling SetMouseCursor(), which is why we have some cursors that are marked unused here
1784enum ImGuiMouseCursor_
1785{
1786 ImGuiMouseCursor_None = -1,
1787 ImGuiMouseCursor_Arrow = 0,
1788 ImGuiMouseCursor_TextInput, // When hovering over InputText, etc.
1789 ImGuiMouseCursor_ResizeAll, // (Unused by Dear ImGui functions)
1790 ImGuiMouseCursor_ResizeNS, // When hovering over an horizontal border
1791 ImGuiMouseCursor_ResizeEW, // When hovering over a vertical border or a column
1792 ImGuiMouseCursor_ResizeNESW, // When hovering over the bottom-left corner of a window
1793 ImGuiMouseCursor_ResizeNWSE, // When hovering over the bottom-right corner of a window
1794 ImGuiMouseCursor_Hand, // (Unused by Dear ImGui functions. Use for e.g. hyperlinks)
1795 ImGuiMouseCursor_NotAllowed, // When hovering something with disallowed interaction. Usually a crossed circle.
1796 ImGuiMouseCursor_COUNT
1797};
1798
1799// Enumeration for ImGui::SetWindow***(), SetNextWindow***(), SetNextItem***() functions
1800// Represent a condition.
1801// Important: Treat as a regular enum! Do NOT combine multiple values using binary operators! All the functions above treat 0 as a shortcut to ImGuiCond_Always.
1802enum ImGuiCond_
1803{
1804 ImGuiCond_None = 0, // No condition (always set the variable), same as _Always
1805 ImGuiCond_Always = 1 << 0, // No condition (always set the variable)
1806 ImGuiCond_Once = 1 << 1, // Set the variable once per runtime session (only the first call will succeed)
1807 ImGuiCond_FirstUseEver = 1 << 2, // Set the variable if the object/window has no persistently saved data (no entry in .ini file)
1808 ImGuiCond_Appearing = 1 << 3 // Set the variable if the object/window is appearing after being hidden/inactive (or the first time)
1809};
1810
1811//-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
1812// [SECTION] Helpers: Memory allocations macros, ImVector<>
1813//-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
1814
1815//-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
1816// IM_MALLOC(), IM_FREE(), IM_NEW(), IM_PLACEMENT_NEW(), IM_DELETE()
1817// We call C++ constructor on own allocated memory via the placement "new(ptr) Type()" syntax.
1818// Defining a custom placement new() with a custom parameter allows us to bypass including <new> which on some platforms complains when user has disabled exceptions.
1819//-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
1820
1821struct ImNewWrapper {};
1822inline void* operator new(size_t, ImNewWrapper, void* ptr) { return ptr; }
1823inline void operator delete(void*, ImNewWrapper, void*) {} // This is only required so we can use the symmetrical new()
1824#define IM_ALLOC(_SIZE) ImGui::MemAlloc(_SIZE)
1825#define IM_FREE(_PTR) ImGui::MemFree(_PTR)
1826#define IM_PLACEMENT_NEW(_PTR) new(ImNewWrapper(), _PTR)
1827#define IM_NEW(_TYPE) new(ImNewWrapper(), ImGui::MemAlloc(sizeof(_TYPE))) _TYPE
1828template<typename T> void IM_DELETE(T* p) { if (p) { p->~T(); ImGui::MemFree(p); } }
1829
1830//-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
1831// ImVector<>
1832// Lightweight std::vector<>-like class to avoid dragging dependencies (also, some implementations of STL with debug enabled are absurdly slow, we bypass it so our code runs fast in debug).
1833//-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
1834// - You generally do NOT need to care or use this ever. But we need to make it available in imgui.h because some of our public structures are relying on it.
1835// - We use std-like naming convention here, which is a little unusual for this codebase.
1836// - Important: clear() frees memory, resize(0) keep the allocated buffer. We use resize(0) a lot to intentionally recycle allocated buffers across frames and amortize our costs.
1837// - Important: our implementation does NOT call C++ constructors/destructors, we treat everything as raw data! This is intentional but be extra mindful of that,
1838// Do NOT use this class as a std::vector replacement in your own code! Many of the structures used by dear imgui can be safely initialized by a zero-memset.
1839//-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
1840
1841IM_MSVC_RUNTIME_CHECKS_OFF
1842template<typename T>
1843struct ImVector
1844{
1845 int Size;
1846 int Capacity;
1847 T* Data;
1848
1849 // Provide standard typedefs but we don't use them ourselves.
1850 typedef T value_type;
1851 typedef value_type* iterator;
1852 typedef const value_type* const_iterator;
1853
1854 // Constructors, destructor
1855 inline ImVector() { Size = Capacity = 0; Data = NULL; }
1856 inline ImVector(const ImVector<T>& src) { Size = Capacity = 0; Data = NULL; operator=(src); }
1857 inline ImVector<T>& operator=(const ImVector<T>& src) { clear(); resize(src.Size); memcpy(Data, src.Data, (size_t)Size * sizeof(T)); return *this; }
1858 inline ~ImVector() { if (Data) IM_FREE(Data); } // Important: does not destruct anything
1859
1860 inline void clear() { if (Data) { Size = Capacity = 0; IM_FREE(Data); Data = NULL; } } // Important: does not destruct anything
1861 inline void clear_delete() { for (int n = 0; n < Size; n++) IM_DELETE(Data[n]); clear(); } // Important: never called automatically! always explicit.
1862 inline void clear_destruct() { for (int n = 0; n < Size; n++) Data[n].~T(); clear(); } // Important: never called automatically! always explicit.
1863
1864 inline bool empty() const { return Size == 0; }
1865 inline int size() const { return Size; }
1866 inline int size_in_bytes() const { return Size * (int)sizeof(T); }
1867 inline int max_size() const { return 0x7FFFFFFF / (int)sizeof(T); }
1868 inline int capacity() const { return Capacity; }
1869 inline T& operator[](int i) { IM_ASSERT(i >= 0 && i < Size); return Data[i]; }
1870 inline const T& operator[](int i) const { IM_ASSERT(i >= 0 && i < Size); return Data[i]; }
1871
1872 inline T* begin() { return Data; }
1873 inline const T* begin() const { return Data; }
1874 inline T* end() { return Data + Size; }
1875 inline const T* end() const { return Data + Size; }
1876 inline T& front() { IM_ASSERT(Size > 0); return Data[0]; }
1877 inline const T& front() const { IM_ASSERT(Size > 0); return Data[0]; }
1878 inline T& back() { IM_ASSERT(Size > 0); return Data[Size - 1]; }
1879 inline const T& back() const { IM_ASSERT(Size > 0); return Data[Size - 1]; }
1880 inline void swap(ImVector<T>& rhs) { int rhs_size = rhs.Size; rhs.Size = Size; Size = rhs_size; int rhs_cap = rhs.Capacity; rhs.Capacity = Capacity; Capacity = rhs_cap; T* rhs_data = rhs.Data; rhs.Data = Data; Data = rhs_data; }
1881
1882 inline int _grow_capacity(int sz) const { int new_capacity = Capacity ? (Capacity + Capacity / 2) : 8; return new_capacity > sz ? new_capacity : sz; }
1883 inline void resize(int new_size) { if (new_size > Capacity) reserve(_grow_capacity(new_size)); Size = new_size; }
1884 inline void resize(int new_size, const T& v) { if (new_size > Capacity) reserve(_grow_capacity(new_size)); if (new_size > Size) for (int n = Size; n < new_size; n++) memcpy(&Data[n], &v, sizeof(v)); Size = new_size; }
1885 inline void shrink(int new_size) { IM_ASSERT(new_size <= Size); Size = new_size; } // Resize a vector to a smaller size, guaranteed not to cause a reallocation
1886 inline void reserve(int new_capacity) { if (new_capacity <= Capacity) return; T* new_data = (T*)IM_ALLOC((size_t)new_capacity * sizeof(T)); if (Data) { memcpy(new_data, Data, (size_t)Size * sizeof(T)); IM_FREE(Data); } Data = new_data; Capacity = new_capacity; }
1887
1888 // NB: It is illegal to call push_back/push_front/insert with a reference pointing inside the ImVector data itself! e.g. v.push_back(v[10]) is forbidden.
1889 inline void push_back(const T& v) { if (Size == Capacity) reserve(_grow_capacity(Size + 1)); memcpy(&Data[Size], &v, sizeof(v)); Size++; }
1890 inline void pop_back() { IM_ASSERT(Size > 0); Size--; }
1891 inline void push_front(const T& v) { if (Size == 0) push_back(v); else insert(Data, v); }
1892 inline T* erase(const T* it) { IM_ASSERT(it >= Data && it < Data + Size); const ptrdiff_t off = it - Data; memmove(Data + off, Data + off + 1, ((size_t)Size - (size_t)off - 1) * sizeof(T)); Size--; return Data + off; }
1893 inline T* erase(const T* it, const T* it_last){ IM_ASSERT(it >= Data && it < Data + Size && it_last >= it && it_last <= Data + Size); const ptrdiff_t count = it_last - it; const ptrdiff_t off = it - Data; memmove(Data + off, Data + off + count, ((size_t)Size - (size_t)off - (size_t)count) * sizeof(T)); Size -= (int)count; return Data + off; }
1894 inline T* erase_unsorted(const T* it) { IM_ASSERT(it >= Data && it < Data + Size); const ptrdiff_t off = it - Data; if (it < Data + Size - 1) memcpy(Data + off, Data + Size - 1, sizeof(T)); Size--; return Data + off; }
1895 inline T* insert(const T* it, const T& v) { IM_ASSERT(it >= Data && it <= Data + Size); const ptrdiff_t off = it - Data; if (Size == Capacity) reserve(_grow_capacity(Size + 1)); if (off < (int)Size) memmove(Data + off + 1, Data + off, ((size_t)Size - (size_t)off) * sizeof(T)); memcpy(&Data[off], &v, sizeof(v)); Size++; return Data + off; }
1896 inline bool contains(const T& v) const { const T* data = Data; const T* data_end = Data + Size; while (data < data_end) if (*data++ == v) return true; return false; }
1897 inline T* find(const T& v) { T* data = Data; const T* data_end = Data + Size; while (data < data_end) if (*data == v) break; else ++data; return data; }
1898 inline const T* find(const T& v) const { const T* data = Data; const T* data_end = Data + Size; while (data < data_end) if (*data == v) break; else ++data; return data; }
1899 inline bool find_erase(const T& v) { const T* it = find(v); if (it < Data + Size) { erase(it); return true; } return false; }
1900 inline bool find_erase_unsorted(const T& v) { const T* it = find(v); if (it < Data + Size) { erase_unsorted(it); return true; } return false; }
1901 inline int index_from_ptr(const T* it) const { IM_ASSERT(it >= Data && it < Data + Size); const ptrdiff_t off = it - Data; return (int)off; }
1902};
1903IM_MSVC_RUNTIME_CHECKS_RESTORE
1904
1905//-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
1906// [SECTION] ImGuiStyle
1907//-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
1908// You may modify the ImGui::GetStyle() main instance during initialization and before NewFrame().
1909// During the frame, use ImGui::PushStyleVar(ImGuiStyleVar_XXXX)/PopStyleVar() to alter the main style values,
1910// and ImGui::PushStyleColor(ImGuiCol_XXX)/PopStyleColor() for colors.
1911//-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
1912
1913struct ImGuiStyle
1914{
1915 float Alpha; // Global alpha applies to everything in Dear ImGui.
1916 float DisabledAlpha; // Additional alpha multiplier applied by BeginDisabled(). Multiply over current value of Alpha.
1917 ImVec2 WindowPadding; // Padding within a window.
1918 float WindowRounding; // Radius of window corners rounding. Set to 0.0f to have rectangular windows. Large values tend to lead to variety of artifacts and are not recommended.
1919 float WindowBorderSize; // Thickness of border around windows. Generally set to 0.0f or 1.0f. (Other values are not well tested and more CPU/GPU costly).
1920 ImVec2 WindowMinSize; // Minimum window size. This is a global setting. If you want to constraint individual windows, use SetNextWindowSizeConstraints().
1921 ImVec2 WindowTitleAlign; // Alignment for title bar text. Defaults to (0.0f,0.5f) for left-aligned,vertically centered.
1922 ImGuiDir WindowMenuButtonPosition; // Side of the collapsing/docking button in the title bar (None/Left/Right). Defaults to ImGuiDir_Left.
1923 float ChildRounding; // Radius of child window corners rounding. Set to 0.0f to have rectangular windows.
1924 float ChildBorderSize; // Thickness of border around child windows. Generally set to 0.0f or 1.0f. (Other values are not well tested and more CPU/GPU costly).
1925 float PopupRounding; // Radius of popup window corners rounding. (Note that tooltip windows use WindowRounding)
1926 float PopupBorderSize; // Thickness of border around popup/tooltip windows. Generally set to 0.0f or 1.0f. (Other values are not well tested and more CPU/GPU costly).
1927 ImVec2 FramePadding; // Padding within a framed rectangle (used by most widgets).
1928 float FrameRounding; // Radius of frame corners rounding. Set to 0.0f to have rectangular frame (used by most widgets).
1929 float FrameBorderSize; // Thickness of border around frames. Generally set to 0.0f or 1.0f. (Other values are not well tested and more CPU/GPU costly).
1930 ImVec2 ItemSpacing; // Horizontal and vertical spacing between widgets/lines.
1931 ImVec2 ItemInnerSpacing; // Horizontal and vertical spacing between within elements of a composed widget (e.g. a slider and its label).
1932 ImVec2 CellPadding; // Padding within a table cell
1933 ImVec2 TouchExtraPadding; // Expand reactive bounding box for touch-based system where touch position is not accurate enough. Unfortunately we don't sort widgets so priority on overlap will always be given to the first widget. So don't grow this too much!
1934 float IndentSpacing; // Horizontal indentation when e.g. entering a tree node. Generally == (FontSize + FramePadding.x*2).
1935 float ColumnsMinSpacing; // Minimum horizontal spacing between two columns. Preferably > (FramePadding.x + 1).
1936 float ScrollbarSize; // Width of the vertical scrollbar, Height of the horizontal scrollbar.
1937 float ScrollbarRounding; // Radius of grab corners for scrollbar.
1938 float GrabMinSize; // Minimum width/height of a grab box for slider/scrollbar.
1939 float GrabRounding; // Radius of grabs corners rounding. Set to 0.0f to have rectangular slider grabs.
1940 float LogSliderDeadzone; // The size in pixels of the dead-zone around zero on logarithmic sliders that cross zero.
1941 float TabRounding; // Radius of upper corners of a tab. Set to 0.0f to have rectangular tabs.
1942 float TabBorderSize; // Thickness of border around tabs.
1943 float TabMinWidthForCloseButton; // Minimum width for close button to appears on an unselected tab when hovered. Set to 0.0f to always show when hovering, set to FLT_MAX to never show close button unless selected.
1944 ImGuiDir ColorButtonPosition; // Side of the color button in the ColorEdit4 widget (left/right). Defaults to ImGuiDir_Right.
1945 ImVec2 ButtonTextAlign; // Alignment of button text when button is larger than text. Defaults to (0.5f, 0.5f) (centered).
1946 ImVec2 SelectableTextAlign; // Alignment of selectable text. Defaults to (0.0f, 0.0f) (top-left aligned). It's generally important to keep this left-aligned if you want to lay multiple items on a same line.
1947 ImVec2 DisplayWindowPadding; // Window position are clamped to be visible within the display area or monitors by at least this amount. Only applies to regular windows.
1948 ImVec2 DisplaySafeAreaPadding; // If you cannot see the edges of your screen (e.g. on a TV) increase the safe area padding. Apply to popups/tooltips as well regular windows. NB: Prefer configuring your TV sets correctly!
1949 float MouseCursorScale; // Scale software rendered mouse cursor (when io.MouseDrawCursor is enabled). We apply per-monitor DPI scaling over this scale. May be removed later.
1950 bool AntiAliasedLines; // Enable anti-aliased lines/borders. Disable if you are really tight on CPU/GPU. Latched at the beginning of the frame (copied to ImDrawList).
1951 bool AntiAliasedLinesUseTex; // Enable anti-aliased lines/borders using textures where possible. Require backend to render with bilinear filtering. Latched at the beginning of the frame (copied to ImDrawList).
1952 bool AntiAliasedFill; // Enable anti-aliased edges around filled shapes (rounded rectangles, circles, etc.). Disable if you are really tight on CPU/GPU. Latched at the beginning of the frame (copied to ImDrawList).
1953 float CurveTessellationTol; // Tessellation tolerance when using PathBezierCurveTo() without a specific number of segments. Decrease for highly tessellated curves (higher quality, more polygons), increase to reduce quality.
1954 float CircleTessellationMaxError; // Maximum error (in pixels) allowed when using AddCircle()/AddCircleFilled() or drawing rounded corner rectangles with no explicit segment count specified. Decrease for higher quality but more geometry.
1955 ImVec4 Colors[ImGuiCol_COUNT];
1956
1957 IMGUI_API ImGuiStyle();
1958 IMGUI_API void ScaleAllSizes(float scale_factor);
1959};
1960
1961//-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
1962// [SECTION] ImGuiIO
1963//-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
1964// Communicate most settings and inputs/outputs to Dear ImGui using this structure.
1965// Access via ImGui::GetIO(). Read 'Programmer guide' section in .cpp file for general usage.
1966//-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
1967
1968// [Internal] Storage used by IsKeyDown(), IsKeyPressed() etc functions.
1969// If prior to 1.87 you used io.KeysDownDuration[] (which was marked as internal), you should use GetKeyData(key)->DownDuration and not io.KeysData[key]->DownDuration.
1970struct ImGuiKeyData
1971{
1972 bool Down; // True for if key is down
1973 float DownDuration; // Duration the key has been down (<0.0f: not pressed, 0.0f: just pressed, >0.0f: time held)
1974 float DownDurationPrev; // Last frame duration the key has been down
1975 float AnalogValue; // 0.0f..1.0f for gamepad values
1976};
1977
1978struct ImGuiIO
1979{
1980 //------------------------------------------------------------------
1981 // Configuration // Default value
1982 //------------------------------------------------------------------
1983
1984 ImGuiConfigFlags ConfigFlags; // = 0 // See ImGuiConfigFlags_ enum. Set by user/application. Gamepad/keyboard navigation options, etc.
1985 ImGuiBackendFlags BackendFlags; // = 0 // See ImGuiBackendFlags_ enum. Set by backend (imgui_impl_xxx files or custom backend) to communicate features supported by the backend.
1986 ImVec2 DisplaySize; // <unset> // Main display size, in pixels (generally == GetMainViewport()->Size). May change every frame.
1987 float DeltaTime; // = 1.0f/60.0f // Time elapsed since last frame, in seconds. May change every frame.
1988 float IniSavingRate; // = 5.0f // Minimum time between saving positions/sizes to .ini file, in seconds.
1989 const char* IniFilename; // = "imgui.ini" // Path to .ini file (important: default "imgui.ini" is relative to current working dir!). Set NULL to disable automatic .ini loading/saving or if you want to manually call LoadIniSettingsXXX() / SaveIniSettingsXXX() functions.
1990 const char* LogFilename; // = "imgui_log.txt"// Path to .log file (default parameter to ImGui::LogToFile when no file is specified).
1991 float MouseDoubleClickTime; // = 0.30f // Time for a double-click, in seconds.
1992 float MouseDoubleClickMaxDist; // = 6.0f // Distance threshold to stay in to validate a double-click, in pixels.
1993 float MouseDragThreshold; // = 6.0f // Distance threshold before considering we are dragging.
1994 float KeyRepeatDelay; // = 0.250f // When holding a key/button, time before it starts repeating, in seconds (for buttons in Repeat mode, etc.).
1995 float KeyRepeatRate; // = 0.050f // When holding a key/button, rate at which it repeats, in seconds.
1996 void* UserData; // = NULL // Store your own data for retrieval by callbacks.
1997
1998 ImFontAtlas*Fonts; // <auto> // Font atlas: load, rasterize and pack one or more fonts into a single texture.
1999 float FontGlobalScale; // = 1.0f // Global scale all fonts
2000 bool FontAllowUserScaling; // = false // Allow user scaling text of individual window with CTRL+Wheel.
2001 ImFont* FontDefault; // = NULL // Font to use on NewFrame(). Use NULL to uses Fonts->Fonts[0].
2002 ImVec2 DisplayFramebufferScale; // = (1, 1) // For retina display or other situations where window coordinates are different from framebuffer coordinates. This generally ends up in ImDrawData::FramebufferScale.
2003
2004 // Docking options (when ImGuiConfigFlags_DockingEnable is set)
2005 bool ConfigDockingNoSplit; // = false // Simplified docking mode: disable window splitting, so docking is limited to merging multiple windows together into tab-bars.
2006 bool ConfigDockingWithShift; // = false // Enable docking with holding Shift key (reduce visual noise, allows dropping in wider space)
2007 bool ConfigDockingAlwaysTabBar; // = false // [BETA] [FIXME: This currently creates regression with auto-sizing and general overhead] Make every single floating window display within a docking node.
2008 bool ConfigDockingTransparentPayload;// = false // [BETA] Make window or viewport transparent when docking and only display docking boxes on the target viewport. Useful if rendering of multiple viewport cannot be synced. Best used with ConfigViewportsNoAutoMerge.
2009
2010 // Viewport options (when ImGuiConfigFlags_ViewportsEnable is set)
2011 bool ConfigViewportsNoAutoMerge; // = false; // Set to make all floating imgui windows always create their own viewport. Otherwise, they are merged into the main host viewports when overlapping it. May also set ImGuiViewportFlags_NoAutoMerge on individual viewport.
2012 bool ConfigViewportsNoTaskBarIcon; // = false // Disable default OS task bar icon flag for secondary viewports. When a viewport doesn't want a task bar icon, ImGuiViewportFlags_NoTaskBarIcon will be set on it.
2013 bool ConfigViewportsNoDecoration; // = true // Disable default OS window decoration flag for secondary viewports. When a viewport doesn't want window decorations, ImGuiViewportFlags_NoDecoration will be set on it. Enabling decoration can create subsequent issues at OS levels (e.g. minimum window size).
2014 bool ConfigViewportsNoDefaultParent; // = false // Disable default OS parenting to main viewport for secondary viewports. By default, viewports are marked with ParentViewportId = <main_viewport>, expecting the platform backend to setup a parent/child relationship between the OS windows (some backend may ignore this). Set to true if you want the default to be 0, then all viewports will be top-level OS windows.
2015
2016 // Miscellaneous options
2017 bool MouseDrawCursor; // = false // Request ImGui to draw a mouse cursor for you (if you are on a platform without a mouse cursor). Cannot be easily renamed to 'io.ConfigXXX' because this is frequently used by backend implementations.
2018 bool ConfigMacOSXBehaviors; // = defined(__APPLE__) // OS X style: Text editing cursor movement using Alt instead of Ctrl, Shortcuts using Cmd/Super instead of Ctrl, Line/Text Start and End using Cmd+Arrows instead of Home/End, Double click selects by word instead of selecting whole text, Multi-selection in lists uses Cmd/Super instead of Ctrl.
2019 bool ConfigInputTrickleEventQueue; // = true // Enable input queue trickling: some types of events submitted during the same frame (e.g. button down + up) will be spread over multiple frames, improving interactions with low framerates.
2020 bool ConfigInputTextCursorBlink; // = true // Enable blinking cursor (optional as some users consider it to be distracting).
2021 bool ConfigDragClickToInputText; // = false // [BETA] Enable turning DragXXX widgets into text input with a simple mouse click-release (without moving). Not desirable on devices without a keyboard.
2022 bool ConfigWindowsResizeFromEdges; // = true // Enable resizing of windows from their edges and from the lower-left corner. This requires (io.BackendFlags & ImGuiBackendFlags_HasMouseCursors) because it needs mouse cursor feedback. (This used to be a per-window ImGuiWindowFlags_ResizeFromAnySide flag)
2023 bool ConfigWindowsMoveFromTitleBarOnly; // = false // Enable allowing to move windows only when clicking on their title bar. Does not apply to windows without a title bar.
2024 float ConfigMemoryCompactTimer; // = 60.0f // Timer (in seconds) to free transient windows/tables memory buffers when unused. Set to -1.0f to disable.
2025
2026 //------------------------------------------------------------------
2027 // Platform Functions
2028 // (the imgui_impl_xxxx backend files are setting those up for you)
2029 //------------------------------------------------------------------
2030
2031 // Optional: Platform/Renderer backend name (informational only! will be displayed in About Window) + User data for backend/wrappers to store their own stuff.
2032 const char* BackendPlatformName; // = NULL
2033 const char* BackendRendererName; // = NULL
2034 void* BackendPlatformUserData; // = NULL // User data for platform backend
2035 void* BackendRendererUserData; // = NULL // User data for renderer backend
2036 void* BackendLanguageUserData; // = NULL // User data for non C++ programming language backend
2037
2038 // Optional: Access OS clipboard
2039 // (default to use native Win32 clipboard on Windows, otherwise uses a private clipboard. Override to access OS clipboard on other architectures)
2040 const char* (*GetClipboardTextFn)(void* user_data);
2041 void (*SetClipboardTextFn)(void* user_data, const char* text);
2042 void* ClipboardUserData;
2043
2044 // Optional: Notify OS Input Method Editor of the screen position of your cursor for text input position (e.g. when using Japanese/Chinese IME on Windows)
2045 // (default to use native imm32 api on Windows)
2046 void (*SetPlatformImeDataFn)(ImGuiViewport* viewport, ImGuiPlatformImeData* data);
2047#ifndef IMGUI_DISABLE_OBSOLETE_FUNCTIONS
2048 void* ImeWindowHandle; // = NULL // [Obsolete] Set ImGuiViewport::PlatformHandleRaw instead. Set this to your HWND to get automatic IME cursor positioning.
2049#else
2050 void* _UnusedPadding; // Unused field to keep data structure the same size.
2051#endif
2052
2053 //------------------------------------------------------------------
2054 // Input - Call before calling NewFrame()
2055 //------------------------------------------------------------------
2056
2057 // Input Functions
2058 IMGUI_API void AddKeyEvent(ImGuiKey key, bool down); // Queue a new key down/up event. Key should be "translated" (as in, generally ImGuiKey_A matches the key end-user would use to emit an 'A' character)
2059 IMGUI_API void AddKeyAnalogEvent(ImGuiKey key, bool down, float v); // Queue a new key down/up event for analog values (e.g. ImGuiKey_Gamepad_ values). Dead-zones should be handled by the backend.
2060 IMGUI_API void AddMousePosEvent(float x, float y); // Queue a mouse position update. Use -FLT_MAX,-FLT_MAX to signify no mouse (e.g. app not focused and not hovered)
2061 IMGUI_API void AddMouseButtonEvent(int button, bool down); // Queue a mouse button change
2062 IMGUI_API void AddMouseWheelEvent(float wh_x, float wh_y); // Queue a mouse wheel update
2063 IMGUI_API void AddMouseViewportEvent(ImGuiID id); // Queue a mouse hovered viewport. Requires backend to set ImGuiBackendFlags_HasMouseHoveredViewport to call this (for multi-viewport support).
2064 IMGUI_API void AddFocusEvent(bool focused); // Queue a gain/loss of focus for the application (generally based on OS/platform focus of your window)
2065 IMGUI_API void AddInputCharacter(unsigned int c); // Queue a new character input
2066 IMGUI_API void AddInputCharacterUTF16(ImWchar16 c); // Queue a new character input from an UTF-16 character, it can be a surrogate
2067 IMGUI_API void AddInputCharactersUTF8(const char* str); // Queue a new characters input from an UTF-8 string
2068
2069 IMGUI_API void ClearInputCharacters(); // [Internal] Clear the text input buffer manually
2070 IMGUI_API void ClearInputKeys(); // [Internal] Release all keys
2071 IMGUI_API void SetKeyEventNativeData(ImGuiKey key, int native_keycode, int native_scancode, int native_legacy_index = -1); // [Optional] Specify index for legacy <1.87 IsKeyXXX() functions with native indices + specify native keycode, scancode.
2072
2073 //------------------------------------------------------------------
2074 // Output - Updated by NewFrame() or EndFrame()/Render()
2075 // (when reading from the io.WantCaptureMouse, io.WantCaptureKeyboard flags to dispatch your inputs, it is
2076 // generally easier and more correct to use their state BEFORE calling NewFrame(). See FAQ for details!)
2077 //------------------------------------------------------------------
2078
2079 bool WantCaptureMouse; // Set when Dear ImGui will use mouse inputs, in this case do not dispatch them to your main game/application (either way, always pass on mouse inputs to imgui). (e.g. unclicked mouse is hovering over an imgui window, widget is active, mouse was clicked over an imgui window, etc.).
2080 bool WantCaptureKeyboard; // Set when Dear ImGui will use keyboard inputs, in this case do not dispatch them to your main game/application (either way, always pass keyboard inputs to imgui). (e.g. InputText active, or an imgui window is focused and navigation is enabled, etc.).
2081 bool WantTextInput; // Mobile/console: when set, you may display an on-screen keyboard. This is set by Dear ImGui when it wants textual keyboard input to happen (e.g. when a InputText widget is active).
2082 bool WantSetMousePos; // MousePos has been altered, backend should reposition mouse on next frame. Rarely used! Set only when ImGuiConfigFlags_NavEnableSetMousePos flag is enabled.
2083 bool WantSaveIniSettings; // When manual .ini load/save is active (io.IniFilename == NULL), this will be set to notify your application that you can call SaveIniSettingsToMemory() and save yourself. Important: clear io.WantSaveIniSettings yourself after saving!
2084 bool NavActive; // Keyboard/Gamepad navigation is currently allowed (will handle ImGuiKey_NavXXX events) = a window is focused and it doesn't use the ImGuiWindowFlags_NoNavInputs flag.
2085 bool NavVisible; // Keyboard/Gamepad navigation is visible and allowed (will handle ImGuiKey_NavXXX events).
2086 float Framerate; // Rough estimate of application framerate, in frame per second. Solely for convenience. Rolling average estimation based on io.DeltaTime over 120 frames.
2087 int MetricsRenderVertices; // Vertices output during last call to Render()
2088 int MetricsRenderIndices; // Indices output during last call to Render() = number of triangles * 3
2089 int MetricsRenderWindows; // Number of visible windows
2090 int MetricsActiveWindows; // Number of active windows
2091 int MetricsActiveAllocations; // Number of active allocations, updated by MemAlloc/MemFree based on current context. May be off if you have multiple imgui contexts.
2092 ImVec2 MouseDelta; // Mouse delta. Note that this is zero if either current or previous position are invalid (-FLT_MAX,-FLT_MAX), so a disappearing/reappearing mouse won't have a huge delta.
2093
2094 // Legacy: before 1.87, we required backend to fill io.KeyMap[] (imgui->native map) during initialization and io.KeysDown[] (native indices) every frame.
2095 // This is still temporarily supported as a legacy feature. However the new preferred scheme is for backend to call io.AddKeyEvent().
2096#ifndef IMGUI_DISABLE_OBSOLETE_KEYIO
2097 int KeyMap[ImGuiKey_COUNT]; // [LEGACY] Input: map of indices into the KeysDown[512] entries array which represent your "native" keyboard state. The first 512 are now unused and should be kept zero. Legacy backend will write into KeyMap[] using ImGuiKey_ indices which are always >512.
2098 bool KeysDown[ImGuiKey_COUNT]; // [LEGACY] Input: Keyboard keys that are pressed (ideally left in the "native" order your engine has access to keyboard keys, so you can use your own defines/enums for keys). This used to be [512] sized. It is now ImGuiKey_COUNT to allow legacy io.KeysDown[GetKeyIndex(...)] to work without an overflow.
2099#endif
2100
2101 //------------------------------------------------------------------
2102 // [Internal] Dear ImGui will maintain those fields. Forward compatibility not guaranteed!
2103 //------------------------------------------------------------------
2104
2105 // Main Input State
2106 // (this block used to be written by backend, since 1.87 it is best to NOT write to those directly, call the AddXXX functions above instead)
2107 // (reading from those variables is fair game, as they are extremely unlikely to be moving anywhere)
2108 ImVec2 MousePos; // Mouse position, in pixels. Set to ImVec2(-FLT_MAX, -FLT_MAX) if mouse is unavailable (on another screen, etc.)
2109 bool MouseDown[5]; // Mouse buttons: 0=left, 1=right, 2=middle + extras (ImGuiMouseButton_COUNT == 5). Dear ImGui mostly uses left and right buttons. Others buttons allows us to track if the mouse is being used by your application + available to user as a convenience via IsMouse** API.
2110 float MouseWheel; // Mouse wheel Vertical: 1 unit scrolls about 5 lines text.
2111 float MouseWheelH; // Mouse wheel Horizontal. Most users don't have a mouse with an horizontal wheel, may not be filled by all backends.
2112 ImGuiID MouseHoveredViewport; // (Optional) Modify using io.AddMouseViewportEvent(). With multi-viewports: viewport the OS mouse is hovering. If possible _IGNORING_ viewports with the ImGuiViewportFlags_NoInputs flag is much better (few backends can handle that). Set io.BackendFlags |= ImGuiBackendFlags_HasMouseHoveredViewport if you can provide this info. If you don't imgui will infer the value using the rectangles and last focused time of the viewports it knows about (ignoring other OS windows).
2113 bool KeyCtrl; // Keyboard modifier down: Control
2114 bool KeyShift; // Keyboard modifier down: Shift
2115 bool KeyAlt; // Keyboard modifier down: Alt
2116 bool KeySuper; // Keyboard modifier down: Cmd/Super/Windows
2117 float NavInputs[ImGuiNavInput_COUNT]; // Gamepad inputs. Cleared back to zero by EndFrame(). Keyboard keys will be auto-mapped and be written here by NewFrame().
2118
2119 // Other state maintained from data above + IO function calls
2120 ImGuiModFlags KeyMods; // Key mods flags (same as io.KeyCtrl/KeyShift/KeyAlt/KeySuper but merged into flags), updated by NewFrame()
2121 ImGuiKeyData KeysData[ImGuiKey_KeysData_SIZE]; // Key state for all known keys. Use IsKeyXXX() functions to access this.
2122 bool WantCaptureMouseUnlessPopupClose; // Alternative to WantCaptureMouse: (WantCaptureMouse == true && WantCaptureMouseUnlessPopupClose == false) when a click over void is expected to close a popup.
2123 ImVec2 MousePosPrev; // Previous mouse position (note that MouseDelta is not necessary == MousePos-MousePosPrev, in case either position is invalid)
2124 ImVec2 MouseClickedPos[5]; // Position at time of clicking
2125 double MouseClickedTime[5]; // Time of last click (used to figure out double-click)
2126 bool MouseClicked[5]; // Mouse button went from !Down to Down (same as MouseClickedCount[x] != 0)
2127 bool MouseDoubleClicked[5]; // Has mouse button been double-clicked? (same as MouseClickedCount[x] == 2)
2128 ImU16 MouseClickedCount[5]; // == 0 (not clicked), == 1 (same as MouseClicked[]), == 2 (double-clicked), == 3 (triple-clicked) etc. when going from !Down to Down
2129 ImU16 MouseClickedLastCount[5]; // Count successive number of clicks. Stays valid after mouse release. Reset after another click is done.
2130 bool MouseReleased[5]; // Mouse button went from Down to !Down
2131 bool MouseDownOwned[5]; // Track if button was clicked inside a dear imgui window or over void blocked by a popup. We don't request mouse capture from the application if click started outside ImGui bounds.
2132 bool MouseDownOwnedUnlessPopupClose[5]; // Track if button was clicked inside a dear imgui window.
2133 float MouseDownDuration[5]; // Duration the mouse button has been down (0.0f == just clicked)
2134 float MouseDownDurationPrev[5]; // Previous time the mouse button has been down
2135 ImVec2 MouseDragMaxDistanceAbs[5]; // Maximum distance, absolute, on each axis, of how much mouse has traveled from the clicking point
2136 float MouseDragMaxDistanceSqr[5]; // Squared maximum distance of how much mouse has traveled from the clicking point (used for moving thresholds)
2137 float NavInputsDownDuration[ImGuiNavInput_COUNT];
2138 float NavInputsDownDurationPrev[ImGuiNavInput_COUNT];
2139 float PenPressure; // Touch/Pen pressure (0.0f to 1.0f, should be >0.0f only when MouseDown[0] == true). Helper storage currently unused by Dear ImGui.
2140 bool AppFocusLost;
2141 ImS8 BackendUsingLegacyKeyArrays; // -1: unknown, 0: using AddKeyEvent(), 1: using legacy io.KeysDown[]
2142 bool BackendUsingLegacyNavInputArray; // 0: using AddKeyAnalogEvent(), 1: writing to legacy io.NavInputs[] directly
2143 ImWchar16 InputQueueSurrogate; // For AddInputCharacterUTF16()
2144 ImVector<ImWchar> InputQueueCharacters; // Queue of _characters_ input (obtained by platform backend). Fill using AddInputCharacter() helper.
2145
2146 IMGUI_API ImGuiIO();
2147};
2148
2149//-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
2150// [SECTION] Misc data structures
2151//-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
2152
2153// Shared state of InputText(), passed as an argument to your callback when a ImGuiInputTextFlags_Callback* flag is used.
2154// The callback function should return 0 by default.
2155// Callbacks (follow a flag name and see comments in ImGuiInputTextFlags_ declarations for more details)
2156// - ImGuiInputTextFlags_CallbackEdit: Callback on buffer edit (note that InputText() already returns true on edit, the callback is useful mainly to manipulate the underlying buffer while focus is active)
2157// - ImGuiInputTextFlags_CallbackAlways: Callback on each iteration
2158// - ImGuiInputTextFlags_CallbackCompletion: Callback on pressing TAB
2159// - ImGuiInputTextFlags_CallbackHistory: Callback on pressing Up/Down arrows
2160// - ImGuiInputTextFlags_CallbackCharFilter: Callback on character inputs to replace or discard them. Modify 'EventChar' to replace or discard, or return 1 in callback to discard.
2161// - ImGuiInputTextFlags_CallbackResize: Callback on buffer capacity changes request (beyond 'buf_size' parameter value), allowing the string to grow.
2162struct ImGuiInputTextCallbackData
2163{
2164 ImGuiInputTextFlags EventFlag; // One ImGuiInputTextFlags_Callback* // Read-only
2165 ImGuiInputTextFlags Flags; // What user passed to InputText() // Read-only
2166 void* UserData; // What user passed to InputText() // Read-only
2167
2168 // Arguments for the different callback events
2169 // - To modify the text buffer in a callback, prefer using the InsertChars() / DeleteChars() function. InsertChars() will take care of calling the resize callback if necessary.
2170 // - If you know your edits are not going to resize the underlying buffer allocation, you may modify the contents of 'Buf[]' directly. You need to update 'BufTextLen' accordingly (0 <= BufTextLen < BufSize) and set 'BufDirty'' to true so InputText can update its internal state.
2171 ImWchar EventChar; // Character input // Read-write // [CharFilter] Replace character with another one, or set to zero to drop. return 1 is equivalent to setting EventChar=0;
2172 ImGuiKey EventKey; // Key pressed (Up/Down/TAB) // Read-only // [Completion,History]
2173 char* Buf; // Text buffer // Read-write // [Resize] Can replace pointer / [Completion,History,Always] Only write to pointed data, don't replace the actual pointer!
2174 int BufTextLen; // Text length (in bytes) // Read-write // [Resize,Completion,History,Always] Exclude zero-terminator storage. In C land: == strlen(some_text), in C++ land: string.length()
2175 int BufSize; // Buffer size (in bytes) = capacity+1 // Read-only // [Resize,Completion,History,Always] Include zero-terminator storage. In C land == ARRAYSIZE(my_char_array), in C++ land: string.capacity()+1
2176 bool BufDirty; // Set if you modify Buf/BufTextLen! // Write // [Completion,History,Always]
2177 int CursorPos; // // Read-write // [Completion,History,Always]
2178 int SelectionStart; // // Read-write // [Completion,History,Always] == to SelectionEnd when no selection)
2179 int SelectionEnd; // // Read-write // [Completion,History,Always]
2180
2181 // Helper functions for text manipulation.
2182 // Use those function to benefit from the CallbackResize behaviors. Calling those function reset the selection.
2183 IMGUI_API ImGuiInputTextCallbackData();
2184 IMGUI_API void DeleteChars(int pos, int bytes_count);
2185 IMGUI_API void InsertChars(int pos, const char* text, const char* text_end = NULL);
2186 void SelectAll() { SelectionStart = 0; SelectionEnd = BufTextLen; }
2187 void ClearSelection() { SelectionStart = SelectionEnd = BufTextLen; }
2188 bool HasSelection() const { return SelectionStart != SelectionEnd; }
2189};
2190
2191// Resizing callback data to apply custom constraint. As enabled by SetNextWindowSizeConstraints(). Callback is called during the next Begin().
2192// NB: For basic min/max size constraint on each axis you don't need to use the callback! The SetNextWindowSizeConstraints() parameters are enough.
2193struct ImGuiSizeCallbackData
2194{
2195 void* UserData; // Read-only. What user passed to SetNextWindowSizeConstraints()
2196 ImVec2 Pos; // Read-only. Window position, for reference.
2197 ImVec2 CurrentSize; // Read-only. Current window size.
2198 ImVec2 DesiredSize; // Read-write. Desired size, based on user's mouse position. Write to this field to restrain resizing.
2199};
2200
2201// [ALPHA] Rarely used / very advanced uses only. Use with SetNextWindowClass() and DockSpace() functions.
2202// Important: the content of this class is still highly WIP and likely to change and be refactored
2203// before we stabilize Docking features. Please be mindful if using this.
2204// Provide hints:
2205// - To the platform backend via altered viewport flags (enable/disable OS decoration, OS task bar icons, etc.)
2206// - To the platform backend for OS level parent/child relationships of viewport.
2207// - To the docking system for various options and filtering.
2208struct ImGuiWindowClass
2209{
2210 ImGuiID ClassId; // User data. 0 = Default class (unclassed). Windows of different classes cannot be docked with each others.
2211 ImGuiID ParentViewportId; // Hint for the platform backend. -1: use default. 0: request platform backend to not parent the platform. != 0: request platform backend to create a parent<>child relationship between the platform windows. Not conforming backends are free to e.g. parent every viewport to the main viewport or not.
2212 ImGuiViewportFlags ViewportFlagsOverrideSet; // Viewport flags to set when a window of this class owns a viewport. This allows you to enforce OS decoration or task bar icon, override the defaults on a per-window basis.
2213 ImGuiViewportFlags ViewportFlagsOverrideClear; // Viewport flags to clear when a window of this class owns a viewport. This allows you to enforce OS decoration or task bar icon, override the defaults on a per-window basis.
2214 ImGuiTabItemFlags TabItemFlagsOverrideSet; // [EXPERIMENTAL] TabItem flags to set when a window of this class gets submitted into a dock node tab bar. May use with ImGuiTabItemFlags_Leading or ImGuiTabItemFlags_Trailing.
2215 ImGuiDockNodeFlags DockNodeFlagsOverrideSet; // [EXPERIMENTAL] Dock node flags to set when a window of this class is hosted by a dock node (it doesn't have to be selected!)
2216 bool DockingAlwaysTabBar; // Set to true to enforce single floating windows of this class always having their own docking node (equivalent of setting the global io.ConfigDockingAlwaysTabBar)
2217 bool DockingAllowUnclassed; // Set to true to allow windows of this class to be docked/merged with an unclassed window. // FIXME-DOCK: Move to DockNodeFlags override?
2218
2219 ImGuiWindowClass() { memset(this, 0, sizeof(*this)); ParentViewportId = (ImGuiID)-1; DockingAllowUnclassed = true; }
2220};
2221
2222// Data payload for Drag and Drop operations: AcceptDragDropPayload(), GetDragDropPayload()
2223struct ImGuiPayload
2224{
2225 // Members
2226 void* Data; // Data (copied and owned by dear imgui)
2227 int DataSize; // Data size
2228
2229 // [Internal]
2230 ImGuiID SourceId; // Source item id
2231 ImGuiID SourceParentId; // Source parent id (if available)
2232 int DataFrameCount; // Data timestamp
2233 char DataType[32 + 1]; // Data type tag (short user-supplied string, 32 characters max)
2234 bool Preview; // Set when AcceptDragDropPayload() was called and mouse has been hovering the target item (nb: handle overlapping drag targets)
2235 bool Delivery; // Set when AcceptDragDropPayload() was called and mouse button is released over the target item.
2236
2237 ImGuiPayload() { Clear(); }
2238 void Clear() { SourceId = SourceParentId = 0; Data = NULL; DataSize = 0; memset(DataType, 0, sizeof(DataType)); DataFrameCount = -1; Preview = Delivery = false; }
2239 bool IsDataType(const char* type) const { return DataFrameCount != -1 && strcmp(type, DataType) == 0; }
2240 bool IsPreview() const { return Preview; }
2241 bool IsDelivery() const { return Delivery; }
2242};
2243
2244// Sorting specification for one column of a table (sizeof == 12 bytes)
2245struct ImGuiTableColumnSortSpecs
2246{
2247 ImGuiID ColumnUserID; // User id of the column (if specified by a TableSetupColumn() call)
2248 ImS16 ColumnIndex; // Index of the column
2249 ImS16 SortOrder; // Index within parent ImGuiTableSortSpecs (always stored in order starting from 0, tables sorted on a single criteria will always have a 0 here)
2250 ImGuiSortDirection SortDirection : 8; // ImGuiSortDirection_Ascending or ImGuiSortDirection_Descending (you can use this or SortSign, whichever is more convenient for your sort function)
2251
2252 ImGuiTableColumnSortSpecs() { memset(this, 0, sizeof(*this)); }
2253};
2254
2255// Sorting specifications for a table (often handling sort specs for a single column, occasionally more)
2256// Obtained by calling TableGetSortSpecs().
2257// When 'SpecsDirty == true' you can sort your data. It will be true with sorting specs have changed since last call, or the first time.
2258// Make sure to set 'SpecsDirty = false' after sorting, else you may wastefully sort your data every frame!
2259struct ImGuiTableSortSpecs
2260{
2261 const ImGuiTableColumnSortSpecs* Specs; // Pointer to sort spec array.
2262 int SpecsCount; // Sort spec count. Most often 1. May be > 1 when ImGuiTableFlags_SortMulti is enabled. May be == 0 when ImGuiTableFlags_SortTristate is enabled.
2263 bool SpecsDirty; // Set to true when specs have changed since last time! Use this to sort again, then clear the flag.
2264
2265 ImGuiTableSortSpecs() { memset(this, 0, sizeof(*this)); }
2266};
2267
2268//-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
2269// [SECTION] Helpers (ImGuiOnceUponAFrame, ImGuiTextFilter, ImGuiTextBuffer, ImGuiStorage, ImGuiListClipper, ImColor)
2270//-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
2271
2272// Helper: Unicode defines
2273#define IM_UNICODE_CODEPOINT_INVALID 0xFFFD // Invalid Unicode code point (standard value).
2274#ifdef IMGUI_USE_WCHAR32
2275#define IM_UNICODE_CODEPOINT_MAX 0x10FFFF // Maximum Unicode code point supported by this build.
2276#else
2277#define IM_UNICODE_CODEPOINT_MAX 0xFFFF // Maximum Unicode code point supported by this build.
2278#endif
2279
2280// Helper: Execute a block of code at maximum once a frame. Convenient if you want to quickly create an UI within deep-nested code that runs multiple times every frame.
2281// Usage: static ImGuiOnceUponAFrame oaf; if (oaf) ImGui::Text("This will be called only once per frame");
2282struct ImGuiOnceUponAFrame
2283{
2284 ImGuiOnceUponAFrame() { RefFrame = -1; }
2285 mutable int RefFrame;
2286 operator bool() const { int current_frame = ImGui::GetFrameCount(); if (RefFrame == current_frame) return false; RefFrame = current_frame; return true; }
2287};
2288
2289// Helper: Parse and apply text filters. In format "aaaaa[,bbbb][,ccccc]"
2290struct ImGuiTextFilter
2291{
2292 IMGUI_API ImGuiTextFilter(const char* default_filter = "");
2293 IMGUI_API bool Draw(const char* label = "Filter (inc,-exc)", float width = 0.0f); // Helper calling InputText+Build
2294 IMGUI_API bool PassFilter(const char* text, const char* text_end = NULL) const;
2295 IMGUI_API void Build();
2296 void Clear() { InputBuf[0] = 0; Build(); }
2297 bool IsActive() const { return !Filters.empty(); }
2298
2299 // [Internal]
2300 struct ImGuiTextRange
2301 {
2302 const char* b;
2303 const char* e;
2304
2305 ImGuiTextRange() { b = e = NULL; }
2306 ImGuiTextRange(const char* _b, const char* _e) { b = _b; e = _e; }
2307 bool empty() const { return b == e; }
2308 IMGUI_API void split(char separator, ImVector<ImGuiTextRange>* out) const;
2309 };
2310 char InputBuf[256];
2311 ImVector<ImGuiTextRange>Filters;
2312 int CountGrep;
2313};
2314
2315// Helper: Growable text buffer for logging/accumulating text
2316// (this could be called 'ImGuiTextBuilder' / 'ImGuiStringBuilder')
2317struct ImGuiTextBuffer
2318{
2319 ImVector<char> Buf;
2320 IMGUI_API static char EmptyString[1];
2321
2322 ImGuiTextBuffer() { }
2323 inline char operator[](int i) const { IM_ASSERT(Buf.Data != NULL); return Buf.Data[i]; }
2324 const char* begin() const { return Buf.Data ? &Buf.front() : EmptyString; }
2325 const char* end() const { return Buf.Data ? &Buf.back() : EmptyString; } // Buf is zero-terminated, so end() will point on the zero-terminator
2326 int size() const { return Buf.Size ? Buf.Size - 1 : 0; }
2327 bool empty() const { return Buf.Size <= 1; }
2328 void clear() { Buf.clear(); }
2329 void reserve(int capacity) { Buf.reserve(capacity); }
2330 const char* c_str() const { return Buf.Data ? Buf.Data : EmptyString; }
2331 IMGUI_API void append(const char* str, const char* str_end = NULL);
2332 IMGUI_API void appendf(const char* fmt, ...) IM_FMTARGS(2);
2333 IMGUI_API void appendfv(const char* fmt, va_list args) IM_FMTLIST(2);
2334};
2335
2336// Helper: Key->Value storage
2337// Typically you don't have to worry about this since a storage is held within each Window.
2338// We use it to e.g. store collapse state for a tree (Int 0/1)
2339// This is optimized for efficient lookup (dichotomy into a contiguous buffer) and rare insertion (typically tied to user interactions aka max once a frame)
2340// You can use it as custom user storage for temporary values. Declare your own storage if, for example:
2341// - You want to manipulate the open/close state of a particular sub-tree in your interface (tree node uses Int 0/1 to store their state).
2342// - You want to store custom debug data easily without adding or editing structures in your code (probably not efficient, but convenient)
2343// Types are NOT stored, so it is up to you to make sure your Key don't collide with different types.
2344struct ImGuiStorage
2345{
2346 // [Internal]
2347 struct ImGuiStoragePair
2348 {
2349 ImGuiID key;
2350 union { int val_i; float val_f; void* val_p; };
2351 ImGuiStoragePair(ImGuiID _key, int _val_i) { key = _key; val_i = _val_i; }
2352 ImGuiStoragePair(ImGuiID _key, float _val_f) { key = _key; val_f = _val_f; }
2353 ImGuiStoragePair(ImGuiID _key, void* _val_p) { key = _key; val_p = _val_p; }
2354 };
2355
2356 ImVector<ImGuiStoragePair> Data;
2357
2358 // - Get***() functions find pair, never add/allocate. Pairs are sorted so a query is O(log N)
2359 // - Set***() functions find pair, insertion on demand if missing.
2360 // - Sorted insertion is costly, paid once. A typical frame shouldn't need to insert any new pair.
2361 void Clear() { Data.clear(); }
2362 IMGUI_API int GetInt(ImGuiID key, int default_val = 0) const;
2363 IMGUI_API void SetInt(ImGuiID key, int val);
2364 IMGUI_API bool GetBool(ImGuiID key, bool default_val = false) const;
2365 IMGUI_API void SetBool(ImGuiID key, bool val);
2366 IMGUI_API float GetFloat(ImGuiID key, float default_val = 0.0f) const;
2367 IMGUI_API void SetFloat(ImGuiID key, float val);
2368 IMGUI_API void* GetVoidPtr(ImGuiID key) const; // default_val is NULL
2369 IMGUI_API void SetVoidPtr(ImGuiID key, void* val);
2370
2371 // - Get***Ref() functions finds pair, insert on demand if missing, return pointer. Useful if you intend to do Get+Set.
2372 // - References are only valid until a new value is added to the storage. Calling a Set***() function or a Get***Ref() function invalidates the pointer.
2373 // - A typical use case where this is convenient for quick hacking (e.g. add storage during a live Edit&Continue session if you can't modify existing struct)
2374 // float* pvar = ImGui::GetFloatRef(key); ImGui::SliderFloat("var", pvar, 0, 100.0f); some_var += *pvar;
2375 IMGUI_API int* GetIntRef(ImGuiID key, int default_val = 0);
2376 IMGUI_API bool* GetBoolRef(ImGuiID key, bool default_val = false);
2377 IMGUI_API float* GetFloatRef(ImGuiID key, float default_val = 0.0f);
2378 IMGUI_API void** GetVoidPtrRef(ImGuiID key, void* default_val = NULL);
2379
2380 // Use on your own storage if you know only integer are being stored (open/close all tree nodes)
2381 IMGUI_API void SetAllInt(int val);
2382
2383 // For quicker full rebuild of a storage (instead of an incremental one), you may add all your contents and then sort once.
2384 IMGUI_API void BuildSortByKey();
2385};
2386
2387// Helper: Manually clip large list of items.
2388// If you have lots evenly spaced items and you have a random access to the list, you can perform coarse
2389// clipping based on visibility to only submit items that are in view.
2390// The clipper calculates the range of visible items and advance the cursor to compensate for the non-visible items we have skipped.
2391// (Dear ImGui already clip items based on their bounds but: it needs to first layout the item to do so, and generally
2392// fetching/submitting your own data incurs additional cost. Coarse clipping using ImGuiListClipper allows you to easily
2393// scale using lists with tens of thousands of items without a problem)
2394// Usage:
2395// ImGuiListClipper clipper;
2396// clipper.Begin(1000); // We have 1000 elements, evenly spaced.
2397// while (clipper.Step())
2398// for (int i = clipper.DisplayStart; i < clipper.DisplayEnd; i++)
2399// ImGui::Text("line number %d", i);
2400// Generally what happens is:
2401// - Clipper lets you process the first element (DisplayStart = 0, DisplayEnd = 1) regardless of it being visible or not.
2402// - User code submit that one element.
2403// - Clipper can measure the height of the first element
2404// - Clipper calculate the actual range of elements to display based on the current clipping rectangle, position the cursor before the first visible element.
2405// - User code submit visible elements.
2406// - The clipper also handles various subtleties related to keyboard/gamepad navigation, wrapping etc.
2407struct ImGuiListClipper
2408{
2409 int DisplayStart; // First item to display, updated by each call to Step()
2410 int DisplayEnd; // End of items to display (exclusive)
2411 int ItemsCount; // [Internal] Number of items
2412 float ItemsHeight; // [Internal] Height of item after a first step and item submission can calculate it
2413 float StartPosY; // [Internal] Cursor position at the time of Begin() or after table frozen rows are all processed
2414 void* TempData; // [Internal] Internal data
2415
2416 // items_count: Use INT_MAX if you don't know how many items you have (in which case the cursor won't be advanced in the final step)
2417 // items_height: Use -1.0f to be calculated automatically on first step. Otherwise pass in the distance between your items, typically GetTextLineHeightWithSpacing() or GetFrameHeightWithSpacing().
2418 IMGUI_API ImGuiListClipper();
2419 IMGUI_API ~ImGuiListClipper();
2420 IMGUI_API void Begin(int items_count, float items_height = -1.0f);
2421 IMGUI_API void End(); // Automatically called on the last call of Step() that returns false.
2422 IMGUI_API bool Step(); // Call until it returns false. The DisplayStart/DisplayEnd fields will be set and you can process/draw those items.
2423
2424 // Call ForceDisplayRangeByIndices() before first call to Step() if you need a range of items to be displayed regardless of visibility.
2425 IMGUI_API void ForceDisplayRangeByIndices(int item_min, int item_max); // item_max is exclusive e.g. use (42, 42+1) to make item 42 always visible BUT due to alignment/padding of certain items it is likely that an extra item may be included on either end of the display range.
2426
2427#ifndef IMGUI_DISABLE_OBSOLETE_FUNCTIONS
2428 inline ImGuiListClipper(int items_count, float items_height = -1.0f) { memset(this, 0, sizeof(*this)); ItemsCount = -1; Begin(items_count, items_height); } // [removed in 1.79]
2429#endif
2430};
2431
2432// Helpers macros to generate 32-bit encoded colors
2433#ifdef IMGUI_USE_BGRA_PACKED_COLOR
2434#define IM_COL32_R_SHIFT 16
2435#define IM_COL32_G_SHIFT 8
2436#define IM_COL32_B_SHIFT 0
2437#define IM_COL32_A_SHIFT 24
2438#define IM_COL32_A_MASK 0xFF000000
2439#else
2440#define IM_COL32_R_SHIFT 0
2441#define IM_COL32_G_SHIFT 8
2442#define IM_COL32_B_SHIFT 16
2443#define IM_COL32_A_SHIFT 24
2444#define IM_COL32_A_MASK 0xFF000000
2445#endif
2446#define IM_COL32(R,G,B,A) (((ImU32)(A)<<IM_COL32_A_SHIFT) | ((ImU32)(B)<<IM_COL32_B_SHIFT) | ((ImU32)(G)<<IM_COL32_G_SHIFT) | ((ImU32)(R)<<IM_COL32_R_SHIFT))
2447#define IM_COL32_WHITE IM_COL32(255,255,255,255) // Opaque white = 0xFFFFFFFF
2448#define IM_COL32_BLACK IM_COL32(0,0,0,255) // Opaque black
2449#define IM_COL32_BLACK_TRANS IM_COL32(0,0,0,0) // Transparent black = 0x00000000
2450
2451// Helper: ImColor() implicitly converts colors to either ImU32 (packed 4x1 byte) or ImVec4 (4x1 float)
2452// Prefer using IM_COL32() macros if you want a guaranteed compile-time ImU32 for usage with ImDrawList API.
2453// **Avoid storing ImColor! Store either u32 of ImVec4. This is not a full-featured color class. MAY OBSOLETE.
2454// **None of the ImGui API are using ImColor directly but you can use it as a convenience to pass colors in either ImU32 or ImVec4 formats. Explicitly cast to ImU32 or ImVec4 if needed.
2455struct ImColor
2456{
2457 ImVec4 Value;
2458
2459 constexpr ImColor() { }
2460 constexpr ImColor(float r, float g, float b, float a = 1.0f) : Value(r, g, b, a) { }
2461 constexpr ImColor(const ImVec4& col) : Value(col) {}
2462 ImColor(int r, int g, int b, int a = 255) { float sc = 1.0f / 255.0f; Value.x = (float)r * sc; Value.y = (float)g * sc; Value.z = (float)b * sc; Value.w = (float)a * sc; }
2463 ImColor(ImU32 rgba) { float sc = 1.0f / 255.0f; Value.x = (float)((rgba >> IM_COL32_R_SHIFT) & 0xFF) * sc; Value.y = (float)((rgba >> IM_COL32_G_SHIFT) & 0xFF) * sc; Value.z = (float)((rgba >> IM_COL32_B_SHIFT) & 0xFF) * sc; Value.w = (float)((rgba >> IM_COL32_A_SHIFT) & 0xFF) * sc; }
2464 inline operator ImU32() const { return ImGui::ColorConvertFloat4ToU32(Value); }
2465 inline operator ImVec4() const { return Value; }
2466
2467 // FIXME-OBSOLETE: May need to obsolete/cleanup those helpers.
2468 inline void SetHSV(float h, float s, float v, float a = 1.0f){ ImGui::ColorConvertHSVtoRGB(h, s, v, Value.x, Value.y, Value.z); Value.w = a; }
2469 static ImColor HSV(float h, float s, float v, float a = 1.0f) { float r, g, b; ImGui::ColorConvertHSVtoRGB(h, s, v, r, g, b); return ImColor(r, g, b, a); }
2470};
2471
2472//-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
2473// [SECTION] Drawing API (ImDrawCmd, ImDrawIdx, ImDrawVert, ImDrawChannel, ImDrawListSplitter, ImDrawListFlags, ImDrawList, ImDrawData)
2474// Hold a series of drawing commands. The user provides a renderer for ImDrawData which essentially contains an array of ImDrawList.
2475//-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
2476
2477// The maximum line width to bake anti-aliased textures for. Build atlas with ImFontAtlasFlags_NoBakedLines to disable baking.
2478#ifndef IM_DRAWLIST_TEX_LINES_WIDTH_MAX
2479#define IM_DRAWLIST_TEX_LINES_WIDTH_MAX (63)
2480#endif
2481
2482// ImDrawCallback: Draw callbacks for advanced uses [configurable type: override in imconfig.h]
2483// NB: You most likely do NOT need to use draw callbacks just to create your own widget or customized UI rendering,
2484// you can poke into the draw list for that! Draw callback may be useful for example to:
2485// A) Change your GPU render state,
2486// B) render a complex 3D scene inside a UI element without an intermediate texture/render target, etc.
2487// The expected behavior from your rendering function is 'if (cmd.UserCallback != NULL) { cmd.UserCallback(parent_list, cmd); } else { RenderTriangles() }'
2488// If you want to override the signature of ImDrawCallback, you can simply use e.g. '#define ImDrawCallback MyDrawCallback' (in imconfig.h) + update rendering backend accordingly.
2489#ifndef ImDrawCallback
2490typedef void (*ImDrawCallback)(const ImDrawList* parent_list, const ImDrawCmd* cmd);
2491#endif
2492
2493// Special Draw callback value to request renderer backend to reset the graphics/render state.
2494// The renderer backend needs to handle this special value, otherwise it will crash trying to call a function at this address.
2495// This is useful for example if you submitted callbacks which you know have altered the render state and you want it to be restored.
2496// It is not done by default because they are many perfectly useful way of altering render state for imgui contents (e.g. changing shader/blending settings before an Image call).
2497#define ImDrawCallback_ResetRenderState (ImDrawCallback)(-1)
2498
2499// Typically, 1 command = 1 GPU draw call (unless command is a callback)
2500// - VtxOffset: When 'io.BackendFlags & ImGuiBackendFlags_RendererHasVtxOffset' is enabled,
2501// this fields allow us to render meshes larger than 64K vertices while keeping 16-bit indices.
2502// Backends made for <1.71. will typically ignore the VtxOffset fields.
2503// - The ClipRect/TextureId/VtxOffset fields must be contiguous as we memcmp() them together (this is asserted for).
2504struct ImDrawCmd
2505{
2506 ImVec4 ClipRect; // 4*4 // Clipping rectangle (x1, y1, x2, y2). Subtract ImDrawData->DisplayPos to get clipping rectangle in "viewport" coordinates
2507 ImTextureID TextureId; // 4-8 // User-provided texture ID. Set by user in ImfontAtlas::SetTexID() for fonts or passed to Image*() functions. Ignore if never using images or multiple fonts atlas.
2508 unsigned int VtxOffset; // 4 // Start offset in vertex buffer. ImGuiBackendFlags_RendererHasVtxOffset: always 0, otherwise may be >0 to support meshes larger than 64K vertices with 16-bit indices.
2509 unsigned int IdxOffset; // 4 // Start offset in index buffer.
2510 unsigned int ElemCount; // 4 // Number of indices (multiple of 3) to be rendered as triangles. Vertices are stored in the callee ImDrawList's vtx_buffer[] array, indices in idx_buffer[].
2511 ImDrawCallback UserCallback; // 4-8 // If != NULL, call the function instead of rendering the vertices. clip_rect and texture_id will be set normally.
2512 void* UserCallbackData; // 4-8 // The draw callback code can access this.
2513
2514 ImDrawCmd() { memset(this, 0, sizeof(*this)); } // Also ensure our padding fields are zeroed
2515
2516 // Since 1.83: returns ImTextureID associated with this draw call. Warning: DO NOT assume this is always same as 'TextureId' (we will change this function for an upcoming feature)
2517 inline ImTextureID GetTexID() const { return TextureId; }
2518};
2519
2520// Vertex layout
2521#ifndef IMGUI_OVERRIDE_DRAWVERT_STRUCT_LAYOUT
2522struct ImDrawVert
2523{
2524 ImVec2 pos;
2525 ImVec2 uv;
2526 ImU32 col;
2527};
2528#else
2529// You can override the vertex format layout by defining IMGUI_OVERRIDE_DRAWVERT_STRUCT_LAYOUT in imconfig.h
2530// The code expect ImVec2 pos (8 bytes), ImVec2 uv (8 bytes), ImU32 col (4 bytes), but you can re-order them or add other fields as needed to simplify integration in your engine.
2531// The type has to be described within the macro (you can either declare the struct or use a typedef). This is because ImVec2/ImU32 are likely not declared a the time you'd want to set your type up.
2532// NOTE: IMGUI DOESN'T CLEAR THE STRUCTURE AND DOESN'T CALL A CONSTRUCTOR SO ANY CUSTOM FIELD WILL BE UNINITIALIZED. IF YOU ADD EXTRA FIELDS (SUCH AS A 'Z' COORDINATES) YOU WILL NEED TO CLEAR THEM DURING RENDER OR TO IGNORE THEM.
2533IMGUI_OVERRIDE_DRAWVERT_STRUCT_LAYOUT;
2534#endif
2535
2536// [Internal] For use by ImDrawList
2537struct ImDrawCmdHeader
2538{
2539 ImVec4 ClipRect;
2540 ImTextureID TextureId;
2541 unsigned int VtxOffset;
2542};
2543
2544// [Internal] For use by ImDrawListSplitter
2545struct ImDrawChannel
2546{
2547 ImVector<ImDrawCmd> _CmdBuffer;
2548 ImVector<ImDrawIdx> _IdxBuffer;
2549};
2550
2551
2552// Split/Merge functions are used to split the draw list into different layers which can be drawn into out of order.
2553// This is used by the Columns/Tables API, so items of each column can be batched together in a same draw call.
2554struct ImDrawListSplitter
2555{
2556 int _Current; // Current channel number (0)
2557 int _Count; // Number of active channels (1+)
2558 ImVector<ImDrawChannel> _Channels; // Draw channels (not resized down so _Count might be < Channels.Size)
2559
2560 inline ImDrawListSplitter() { memset(this, 0, sizeof(*this)); }
2561 inline ~ImDrawListSplitter() { ClearFreeMemory(); }
2562 inline void Clear() { _Current = 0; _Count = 1; } // Do not clear Channels[] so our allocations are reused next frame
2563 IMGUI_API void ClearFreeMemory();
2564 IMGUI_API void Split(ImDrawList* draw_list, int count);
2565 IMGUI_API void Merge(ImDrawList* draw_list);
2566 IMGUI_API void SetCurrentChannel(ImDrawList* draw_list, int channel_idx);
2567};
2568
2569// Flags for ImDrawList functions
2570// (Legacy: bit 0 must always correspond to ImDrawFlags_Closed to be backward compatible with old API using a bool. Bits 1..3 must be unused)
2571enum ImDrawFlags_
2572{
2573 ImDrawFlags_None = 0,
2574 ImDrawFlags_Closed = 1 << 0, // PathStroke(), AddPolyline(): specify that shape should be closed (Important: this is always == 1 for legacy reason)
2575 ImDrawFlags_RoundCornersTopLeft = 1 << 4, // AddRect(), AddRectFilled(), PathRect(): enable rounding top-left corner only (when rounding > 0.0f, we default to all corners). Was 0x01.
2576 ImDrawFlags_RoundCornersTopRight = 1 << 5, // AddRect(), AddRectFilled(), PathRect(): enable rounding top-right corner only (when rounding > 0.0f, we default to all corners). Was 0x02.
2577 ImDrawFlags_RoundCornersBottomLeft = 1 << 6, // AddRect(), AddRectFilled(), PathRect(): enable rounding bottom-left corner only (when rounding > 0.0f, we default to all corners). Was 0x04.
2578 ImDrawFlags_RoundCornersBottomRight = 1 << 7, // AddRect(), AddRectFilled(), PathRect(): enable rounding bottom-right corner only (when rounding > 0.0f, we default to all corners). Wax 0x08.
2579 ImDrawFlags_RoundCornersNone = 1 << 8, // AddRect(), AddRectFilled(), PathRect(): disable rounding on all corners (when rounding > 0.0f). This is NOT zero, NOT an implicit flag!
2580 ImDrawFlags_RoundCornersTop = ImDrawFlags_RoundCornersTopLeft | ImDrawFlags_RoundCornersTopRight,
2581 ImDrawFlags_RoundCornersBottom = ImDrawFlags_RoundCornersBottomLeft | ImDrawFlags_RoundCornersBottomRight,
2582 ImDrawFlags_RoundCornersLeft = ImDrawFlags_RoundCornersBottomLeft | ImDrawFlags_RoundCornersTopLeft,
2583 ImDrawFlags_RoundCornersRight = ImDrawFlags_RoundCornersBottomRight | ImDrawFlags_RoundCornersTopRight,
2584 ImDrawFlags_RoundCornersAll = ImDrawFlags_RoundCornersTopLeft | ImDrawFlags_RoundCornersTopRight | ImDrawFlags_RoundCornersBottomLeft | ImDrawFlags_RoundCornersBottomRight,
2585 ImDrawFlags_RoundCornersDefault_ = ImDrawFlags_RoundCornersAll, // Default to ALL corners if none of the _RoundCornersXX flags are specified.
2586 ImDrawFlags_RoundCornersMask_ = ImDrawFlags_RoundCornersAll | ImDrawFlags_RoundCornersNone
2587};
2588
2589// Flags for ImDrawList instance. Those are set automatically by ImGui:: functions from ImGuiIO settings, and generally not manipulated directly.
2590// It is however possible to temporarily alter flags between calls to ImDrawList:: functions.
2591enum ImDrawListFlags_
2592{
2593 ImDrawListFlags_None = 0,
2594 ImDrawListFlags_AntiAliasedLines = 1 << 0, // Enable anti-aliased lines/borders (*2 the number of triangles for 1.0f wide line or lines thin enough to be drawn using textures, otherwise *3 the number of triangles)
2595 ImDrawListFlags_AntiAliasedLinesUseTex = 1 << 1, // Enable anti-aliased lines/borders using textures when possible. Require backend to render with bilinear filtering.
2596 ImDrawListFlags_AntiAliasedFill = 1 << 2, // Enable anti-aliased edge around filled shapes (rounded rectangles, circles).
2597 ImDrawListFlags_AllowVtxOffset = 1 << 3 // Can emit 'VtxOffset > 0' to allow large meshes. Set when 'ImGuiBackendFlags_RendererHasVtxOffset' is enabled.
2598};
2599
2600// Draw command list
2601// This is the low-level list of polygons that ImGui:: functions are filling. At the end of the frame,
2602// all command lists are passed to your ImGuiIO::RenderDrawListFn function for rendering.
2603// Each dear imgui window contains its own ImDrawList. You can use ImGui::GetWindowDrawList() to
2604// access the current window draw list and draw custom primitives.
2605// You can interleave normal ImGui:: calls and adding primitives to the current draw list.
2606// In single viewport mode, top-left is == GetMainViewport()->Pos (generally 0,0), bottom-right is == GetMainViewport()->Pos+Size (generally io.DisplaySize).
2607// You are totally free to apply whatever transformation matrix to want to the data (depending on the use of the transformation you may want to apply it to ClipRect as well!)
2608// Important: Primitives are always added to the list and not culled (culling is done at higher-level by ImGui:: functions), if you use this API a lot consider coarse culling your drawn objects.
2609struct ImDrawList
2610{
2611 // This is what you have to render
2612 ImVector<ImDrawCmd> CmdBuffer; // Draw commands. Typically 1 command = 1 GPU draw call, unless the command is a callback.
2613 ImVector<ImDrawIdx> IdxBuffer; // Index buffer. Each command consume ImDrawCmd::ElemCount of those
2614 ImVector<ImDrawVert> VtxBuffer; // Vertex buffer.
2615 ImDrawListFlags Flags; // Flags, you may poke into these to adjust anti-aliasing settings per-primitive.
2616
2617 // [Internal, used while building lists]
2618 unsigned int _VtxCurrentIdx; // [Internal] generally == VtxBuffer.Size unless we are past 64K vertices, in which case this gets reset to 0.
2619 const ImDrawListSharedData* _Data; // Pointer to shared draw data (you can use ImGui::GetDrawListSharedData() to get the one from current ImGui context)
2620 const char* _OwnerName; // Pointer to owner window's name for debugging
2621 ImDrawVert* _VtxWritePtr; // [Internal] point within VtxBuffer.Data after each add command (to avoid using the ImVector<> operators too much)
2622 ImDrawIdx* _IdxWritePtr; // [Internal] point within IdxBuffer.Data after each add command (to avoid using the ImVector<> operators too much)
2623 ImVector<ImVec4> _ClipRectStack; // [Internal]
2624 ImVector<ImTextureID> _TextureIdStack; // [Internal]
2625 ImVector<ImVec2> _Path; // [Internal] current path building
2626 ImDrawCmdHeader _CmdHeader; // [Internal] template of active commands. Fields should match those of CmdBuffer.back().
2627 ImDrawListSplitter _Splitter; // [Internal] for channels api (note: prefer using your own persistent instance of ImDrawListSplitter!)
2628 float _FringeScale; // [Internal] anti-alias fringe is scaled by this value, this helps to keep things sharp while zooming at vertex buffer content
2629
